DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
Eds: AMer planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against major foreign currencies Wednesday in hectic but thin European trading after the U.S. military intervention in Panama. Gold prices were lower. Traders said the dollar was boosted early in the trading day by the U.S. military action and by an unexpected upward revision in the third-quarter U.S. economic growth rate. The dollar stabilized later in the day, traders said, and then slipped back in mild profit-taking. ``We think (the Panama situation) is very much a smoke screen and an excuse to buy dollars,'' said one London dealer. ``If the market was genuinely frightened from the news, why didn't gold also gain?'' Investors traditionally turn to the dollar and gold as safe havens in times of turmoil. Traders cautioned against drawing too many conclusions from dollar movements in the market, thinned by the holiday season. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 144.23 Japanese yen from 143.80 yen at Tuesday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 143.90 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6052 from $1.6005 late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.7355 West German marks, down from 1.7365; 1.5585 Swiss francs, down from 1.5615; 5.9165 French francs, down from 5.9300; 1.9720 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9575; 1,288.00 Italian lire, down from 1,291.25; and 1.1625 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1613. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $413.50 a troy ounce, down from $413.75 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal fell to a closing bid of $413 dollars, down from $414 dollars bid late Tuesday. In Hong Kong, gold fell 76 cents to close at a bid $412.04. Silver bullion fell in London to a late bid price of $5.56 a troy ounce, down from $5.57 bid late Tuesday.
